entry.content:
You people have nothing to worry about, you’ll get jobs easily. The problem is for people like us

Ankur quipped while we are discussing the prospects of getting job after college.

We are discussing the prospects of getting job after college. The uncertainty caused by past IT recessions trigger this. Weather is pleasant. We are sitting outside a Nirulas’ under picnic umbrellas. This is part of a laid back market complex which does not do much business. It is walking distance from college, we love to take a long walk from college to here.

Ashish has been kicked out from the group, and some friends choose to stay with him. I wanted to, but I choose to stay where Anusha seems to be comfortable. This has reduced the number from around 15 to 5. We are bunking some class, sitting outside a food joint. I am holding Anusha’s hand, she might have felt my hand twitch.

Being a perennial back bencher and flunking in numerous examinations (total 5 papers till now), I do not know how to respond to this unexpected attack. Being a SC/ST student, it has become apparent to me that I cannot be just lazy, average or not interested, I am just an incompetent loser who does not deserve to sit between these enlightened beings. They seem to be doing me a favor by caring to listen to me.

After a long silence, considering the path of least resistance, i decided to change the topic.

The job market is difficult after the recession. All of us have some hard time ahead of us

But the Jack Maa look alike had to make make his point.

Why do you why people like you would look into the private job market? There’s so many of amazing opportunities available in the government sector. And believe me, you will earn far more than the private sector

Oh, somebody say something……silence!!

It’s not for everyone to see things your way.

I think that ended the discussion.

Oh, the crucial part of this open discrimination practiced by teachers, students and even chaprasis of this great institute – Bharati Vidyapeeth, Delhi and the even greater dumb-ass university it represents – Guru Gobind Singh Indraprastha University, was allocating the roll numbers – I think first 6 roll numbers represent the reserved community – SC/STs or chuda/chamar as thought of by the these enlightened and entitled middle class chutias.

I looked at Anusha as she is looking into my eyes. She is asking me to ignore this, but I cant seem to decide. We decide to go back to college. She has been one of those rare humans who has offered me parity – of thought, ability….respect of being treated like another human being.

We were happy gang of 15 middle class misfits, who who liked each other some of them had romantic inclinations. Some things have changed. Now we are 5/7 people (2 of them cant seem to decide).

Anusha is like a friend I never deserved or worked for. Of all the people in my life, I think she is the only one who feels what I am going through. I have never shared details of the legal and moral issues I am facing at home, but she only knows about Gunjan, and how I am still deeply in love with a with her.

I feel i am selfishly using her. I have no prospects, a loser to the core, still she prefers me. Even I don’t prefer myself these days. She still does.

Gunjan….I don’t know if she will be back or she has gone for good. I cant stop thinking about her. Maybe she is dating a stud she deserves…maybe she is being tricked by one of the thousand bastards who seem to be following her day and night. Anyways, I don’t seem to deserve her. She has a good idea or some suspicion of me being an undeserving chamar who tricked her into accepting my proposal…..good that nothing happened….this guilt of tricking her would have killed me.

Here is Anusha, the best of girls I would ever meet….holding my hand despite knowing my reality. I can feel love when she holds my hand.

And I don’t know how it happened. I don’t even remember the first time I held her hand, it seemed to have happened spontaneously.

As far as i can remember, she was talking me about a guy she seemed to have been dating, and it did not end well…i understood….and maybe that is how we became friends.

Much of the things between us seemed to be unsaid. She will wait for me, I would wait for her….find any simple excuse to be with her…..go on long walks….bunk classes to be with her. She did not seem to mind sitting on my old scooter.

She somehow understood….and I could feel her….her hands told me all i needed to know….some weird telepathy shit….or i am delusional.

I know what hurts her, I know when I hurt her, and how could I make it alright. She never hurt me…..and when she did….it was brutal

Coming back to the present moment,This awkward argument means Jack Maa is targeting me now. After kicking Ashish and his loyalists out, everyone in this leftover group of 7 is a bloody beta, all ugly, short or severely limited in intellect….basically an un-date-able set of severely undeserving poor specimen of the male form. No one Anusha or any conscious female or any functional girl would ever consider.

Or am I about to be proved wrong???

entry.content:
I did not knew that the issue of caste discrimination is widespread in the world, let alone India.

Recently an ignorant asshole of general garbage origin shared an article which kind of forced me to increase the priority of this rather dead blog.

How India’s ancient caste system is ruining lives in Silicon Valley

WashingtonPost : A new lawsuit shines a light on caste discrimination in the U.S. and around the world

The Cisco Case Could Expose Rampant Prejudice Against Dalits in Silicon Valley

For the uninitiated, Chamar is one of the sub castes, which also comes under rather lager or politically correct term Dalit.

Though centuries have passed, the discrimination remains prevalent as ever.

Most people generally assume that people belonging to this category of caste have an easy, express path to professional success and prosperity, A notion which i aim to challenge and provide a real life view.

I can only cover the aspects which i have faced in the most objective manner, to provide an unbiased perspective.

entry.content:
I loved you. Something in me still loves and misses you.

My long due closure.

Anusha, of all the females i have known in my life, you were the most kind, affectionate, intelligent and million other good things.

You were flawless.

I really wanted to be good for you….for the fact that i could not imagine not having your voice in my life.

As you had given hundreds of hours of me whining about my ex girlfriend Gunjan, I wanted to be sure.

For me, you were pure….an angel….maybe a god.

I really wanted to be sure, when i commit to you I commit for good, not as a insecure rebound from Gunjan…….you were the nicest.

And that time never arrived, and i was sure that it may never. I have not ever really gotten over Gunjan…and i really knew that you have bigger things in store for you….to me it seemed like you chose to score low….your potential was infinite….and I am a chamar boy ….getting Rs 20 a week, who just wanted to die.

And it got worse….skin gave away….and so did my belief of me being destined for self destruction.

I did misbehave with you and probably cheated you emotionally…..but you have to understand….you were the only good in my life back then.

I never really blamed for what happened next…i knew i deserved it….but i would have heard it from you.

It may be possible yet improbable that you might carry some guilt of what happened. Hope this helps….i deserved it and i am sorry.

I still miss you….for you are the only person who may still understand me.

For me, you are still the only person who is truly broken me…..it feels like you still have a part of me, and i still have yours. I still feel you…i still understand your emotions your hands your breath and those thousand different emotions your beautiful eyes conveyed.

I still imagine me exhaling on you soft skin and feeling your scent.

entry.content:
Who

I am a Chamar boy, born in a somewhat normal middle class (not Chamar middle class, normal middle class) family.

I was born in 1981 in a semi-urban village in Delhi.

My father had a Bajaj Super in 1990, and we got a landline telephone in 1997.

I know it’s hard to imagine a village in Delhi now, but in 1990 till the time we stayed there, it had a water well, we had cows and cow dung was the primary fuel though my father got us LPG ever since i can remember.

So now here we are. Year is 2020, the most chaotic year for my generation, but somehow I am better placed than I ever was.

I have a spacious (in most senses) house, 2 cars, 2 dogs, a beautiful and intelligent son and mostly loving wife.

And I work at Facebook.

That is the big reveal. 2 Cr.

That declaration is not an achievement, I just want my readers to know what they are dealing with here.

This Facebook and the money thing seems important to society.

Apparently it kind of justifies my existence. People are nicer.

Hypocrisy of society becomes very apparent when you are even minutely successful.

Ever since I have realized what Chamar is, and how apparently we have special powers given by the constitution, a subject of envy and inflammatory debates on social media and hushed discussion in social circles.

Why

As I am getting older, I do tend to think about the past, mostly to learn from it. I remember those days, when my self worth was negative million.

I was targeted, gaslit at college, did not take it well, slipped in a depression, developed Psoriasis, spent years in a sham ayurvedic ashram with skin swollen like a balloon filled with pus covered in cow dung.

Abandonment by the girl I loved, the girl who loved me, friends, my own family. A failed suicide attempt, living through vengeance, death of father, a sister which destroyed the family, destroyed my existence.

All because I am a Chamar.

It was not all bad, It somehow made me realize the strengths which I thought I never had, and did generally well. Something kept me pushing, and I kept breathing.

I want to share my journey with you. Anyone who feels like I did in my Chamar years can get some semblance of hope or direction and hopefully he/she does not commit the grave mistakes I did, or felt like how I felt.

To Readers

I hope you get a balanced view of a Chamar life and hopefully next time you feel like feeling taller, maybe you will be empathetic to the SC/ST humanoid in your class, office or school.

If you feel like saying stuff, you have the full freedom to give me a piece of your mind, absolutely brutally.

I have will update the blog in a way that anonymous are welcome and give me their best shot. It’s sort of a fuel to me now.

To my fellow Chamaar/SC/ST Readers

I hope you learn.

I hope you feel hopeful.

I hope you can believe in yourself, rather than what society is telling you silently.

If my journey can benefit any one of you, my efforts would make sense to me.

How

I will try to narrate it in a novel kind of style.

You already know where I am.

Logically my story starts in class 11, when I started realizing the implications of being a chamar, what it meant for career, for making friends, girls and neighborhood.

I have changed certain key details, to preserve the identity of the people involved.

I will narrate the journey, leaving the judgment to readers.
